stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on first-pass 3-D modelling for Course 15 "Astral Arcade" – a space-pinball level – defining the core interactive pieces (flipper paddle, spherical bumper, triangular bumper, trampoline button, decorative metal platforms) and rough layout (open central hub with disconnected pinball parts floating beneath, accessed through warps). He wrestles mainly with visual/functional design of the spherical bumper. The session also veers into sponsor chatter, a revived side commission (open-world GTA-style hack), and mic/sunflower-seed tangents.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 will adopt a Mario-Galaxy approach: appear open yet stay linear via multiple short, intersecting paths and warps between floating pinball elements.
development_findings.quote: "This level is gonna have a Mario Galaxy type design philosophy – feel open but be linear… a bunch of random linear paths that somewhat intersect."

development_findings.summary: Core interactive pieces list finalised: flipper paddle that rotates and launches upward, spherical bumper that returns the player along the incoming vector, triangular bumper that ejects in its pointing direction, trampoline/button that shoots upward, plus non-interactive metal platforms.
Decision to model gameplay parts first, then unify visual theme later once all pieces exist.
development_findings.quote: "I think I should have all the pieces first and then we try to make them visually coherent – doing that before seems hopeless."

development_findings.summary: Technical challenge: making a fully spherical bumper read visually as a ‘bumper’ in 3-D; considered half-sphere fallback, transparent shells with a static core, glowing decals, attached spring models.
development_findings.quote: "The non-hemisphere is just impossible… maybe a transparent thing around it and a static core… I think I see a vision."

development_findings.summary: Constraint: pieces must work in full 3-D space (no back walls) and cannot grant coins.
development_findings.quote: "We have to keep in mind they have to work in 3-D space… we can't do anything that gives you coins."

development_findings.summary: Biobak will later polish/improve the temporary models and textures Kaze blocked out.
development_findings.quote: "I'm sure Biobak will improve this anyway – for now it's fine."

development_findings.summary: Kaze is experimenting in Blender; mentions FAST64 prompting material-upgrade alerts when files open.
Off-stream time this week diverted to finish an old paid commission – an edgy open-world ‘drug dealing’ hack with multiple cities, radios, and crime mechanics.
development_findings.quote: "This hack is gonna keep me very busy over the next few days… I can't just leave the hack where it is."

development_findings.summary: Upcoming technical R&D videos: exploiting an extra unused 1 MB of N64 RAM and deep dive into the console cache – discoveries may feed future optimisation in Return to Yoshi’s Island.
development_findings.quote: "There's like an entire megabyte of N64 memory we can use… that's insane."

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels increasingly annoyed by YouTube comments recently.
context_findings.quote: "I don't know what it is, but recently I've been getting so much more annoyed at my YouTube comments…"

context_findings.summary: Room is uncomfortably cold; struggling with heavy new microphone that lacks proper stand.
Philosophy on skills: claims innate aptitude for programming; modelling is ‘piss easy’ once you read documentation; cites ‘Thinking, Fast and Slow’ for decision making.
context_findings.quote: "Programming is not something I had to learn… I was born with the ability; I just had to learn the grammar."

context_findings.summary: Financial time-sink: completing long-standing commission because client paid again; acknowledges it reduces time for main project.
Mentions spouse/animator Zeina only indirectly (no new collaborative info).

biobak.summary: Will take Kaze’s placeholder models/textures and refine them for final quality.

key_stories.title: The Impossible 3-D Bumper
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles to design a spherical pinball bumper that clearly communicates its function in 3-D. He iterates through textures, glowing decals, half-sphere compromises, and even transparent shells with springs.
key_stories.challenge: A full sphere doesn't visually read as a ‘bumper’ and looks ugly.
key_stories.process: Tried triangle tessellations, beach-ball textures, glowing rings, then considered half-sphere or transparent shell with static core and billboarded rings.
key_stories.outcome: No final asset yet; decided to park visuals, keep provisional model, and revisit after other pieces exist.
key_stories.key_quote: "The non-hemisphere is just impossible… I think we should just take the L for now."

key_stories.title: Old Commission Resurfaces
key_stories.summary: A previously dormant paid project – an open-world ‘drug city’ hack – is revived when the client sends more money, forcing Kaze to split focus.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing time between Return to Yoshi’s Island and the recommissioned hack.
key_stories.process: Shows a build with New York, radios, drug sales, cops; explains obligation to finish it first.
key_stories.outcome: Will occupy next few days, slowing progress on Astral Arcade.
key_stories.key_quote: "I have to do this now – I can't just leave the hack where it is."

key_stories.title: Sunflower-Seed Sponsorship Bit
key_stories.summary: Smackin' Sunflower Seeds ships free products and asks Kaze to eat them on stream for future affiliate deal.
key_stories.challenge: On-stream product integration without formal agreement or link.
key_stories.process: Eats seeds live, discusses commission structure (20% cut, 10% viewer discount).
key_stories.outcome: No link yet; plans to sort details next week.
key_stories.key_quote: "I don't know what my link is, so I can't give you the discount yet – just wait until next week."
